tweet_text: Question üôã‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è a topic that is not typical for me haha! I know significantly less about cars than child safety, and would appreciate anyone‚Äôs helpful thoughts. We bought a car 14 months ago. It had about 12000kms on it, was from a very reputable dealership and a very highly regarded manufacturer (or so we thought) with a new car manufacturers warranty on it. It wasn‚Äôt a cheap car, it was needed to meet the needs of a family with pets and kids etc - it is one of two 7 seaters with the ability to tow a caravan, that I can drive with my spinal injury. It was an investment in lifestyle and something we chose to spend a bit on knowing it would lead to lots of adventures together. It broke down 3 times in the first 5 weeks, with the third time resulting in it being towed (again) to the dealership and they have had it FOR OVER 12 MONTHS.  During this time; we have been told a litany of lies, inconsistencies and been bullied extensively. We waited for our car to be repaired, under immense pressure from the dealer principal who consistently told us there were no parts available in the world (seriously) to fix it.  We were told we had to accept a refund (and sign an NDA) that the manufacturer would cover to the best of our knowledge, around the same time as learning that the same guy had ordered the genuine parts to repair our car, presumably to sell it a second time whilst the manufacturer paid us a refund. A year later, a refund doesn‚Äôt come close to covering our costs let alone to covering the cost of replacing the car with one similar.  The dealer principal allegedly has a history of misconduct, bullying and skimming staffs commission - he was marched out of the same dealership a few years back, only to inexplicably be put back in that same role, where he has continued to put consumers and I‚Äôm guessing staff, at risk. The company that did this, owns hundreds of dealerships Australia wide.  9 or so days after that last absurd claim that not a part in the world was available (it‚Äôs a DPF issue, in a fairly new car), after we reluctantly escalated it to the Head Office, we were told it was miraculously repaired and ready. We were over the moon. But. We got it, and despite being told it was undrivable and unrepairable for a year (by the dealership - the manufacturer was actually helpful) it has an additional 6000kms on the odometer üò¨üòî They are refusing to explain this. It has broken down AGAIN; on the weekend and has been towed again. We had it back for 9 days. Bringing the total time it has been in our possession to five weeks out of 14 months of ownership.  We don‚Äôt have a car I can drive now, with small kids who need to go to school, a bush property that is in a fire zone with no way to evacuate and quite frankly - I‚Äôm so over powerful bullies trampling ppl.  We bought this vehicle as something nice for our family on the back of the Commission of Inquiry stress, to go on road trips in and have time together recovering from the previous 4 years of work in Tasmania. What are our rights here? The Australian consumer law seems quite straight forwards re conduct and obligations. But they seem to be unwilling to adhere to it. We are concerned for all other consumers too. üò£ This is the largest automotive group in the country.  Why would we accept a refund if it would mean we lose our car, the extended warranty the manufacturer gave us and the ability to purchase another because they have gone up in price so much? Especially after being victims to so much deceptive and misleading conduct. The dealer principal was shuffled to another ‚Äòreputable‚Äô dealership last week. ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è (GODDAMNIT NOT MORE OF THE SHUFFLING‚Ä¶) Just want my car to be honest. Would like to take my kids to school. Arrrrgghhh any help deeply appreciated! What do we do?! üôè @acccgovau @APEagersLimited @ACurrentAffair9 @jmwhistleblower @JonDeeOz @Richard_D_Boyle @michaelatkin @ConsumerWA @davidchau @MercedesBenz @abcperth @abcnews

Upon bringing my vehicle in on March 21st, I was informed that the technicians needed to inspect the wiring around the soot sensor, followed by the replacement of the sensor itself. These additional services amounted to a further ¬£906.60. Despite these efforts, today, April 25th, the engine light has once again illuminated, indicating that the initial issue was not resolved. This suggests that I was charged for services that failed to address the root cause of the problem.
